questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with sudden hives, facial swelling, and difficulty breathing shortly after eating shrimp at a restaurant. She reports similar reactions in the past. She appears anxious, with pronounced facial swelling and wheezing. Which sequence correctly describes the immunological events in this type of reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Allergen exposure → Mast cell activation → IgE production → Th2 cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators

options.label: B
options.text: Th2 cell activation → Allergen exposure → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators

options.label: C
options.text: Allergen exposure → Th2 cell activation → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators

options.label: D
options.text: Allergen exposure → Th2 cell activation → Mast cell activation → IgE production → Release of inflammatory mediators

questions.correct_answer: C. Allergen exposure → Th2 cell activation → IgE production → Mast cell activation → Release of inflammatory mediators
questions.explanation:
Synonyms
  • Immediate hypersensitivity
  • Allergy

Features

Occurs in previously sensitised individuals to an antigen, where the antigen binds to IgE antibodies on mast cells

Types
  • Local
  • Systemic

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to IgE and promotes the development of additional Th2 cells in type I hypersensitivity reactions?

options.label: A
options.text: IL-4

options.label: B
options.text: IL-5

options.label: C
options.text: IL-13

options.label: D
options.text: IL-10

questions.explanation:
Interleukins

Role

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells

IL-5 (Option B)

Development and activation of eosinophils→ Recruited to the site of allergen exposure→ Release inflammatory mediators and enzymes→ Tissue damage and inflammation

IL-13 (Option C)
  • Amplifies IgE production
  • Acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion

IL-10 (Option D)
  • Anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • Inhibits cytokine production by Th1 cells and macrophages.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of allergic asthma presents with worsening respiratory symptoms. The sputum sample shows the presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with this phase of hypersensitivity reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Recruitment of eosinophils to the site of inflammation by chemokines like eotaxin

options.label: B
options.text: Production of IL-5 by Th2 cells to activate eosinophils

options.label: C
options.text: Release of histamine and tryptase by eosinophils

options.label: D
options.text: Liberation of major basic protein and eosinophil cationic protein by activated eosinophils

questions.correct_answer: C. Release of histamine and tryptase by eosinophils
questions.explanation:
Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF).

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin)

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach
  • Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.
  • Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Graft rejection

options.label: B
options.text: Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis

options.label: C
options.text: Casoni test

options.label: D
options.text: P-K reactions

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not an example of a Type II hypersensitivity reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Rheumatic fever

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple sclerosis

options.label: C
options.text: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

options.label: D
options.text: Pernicious anaemia

questions.explanation:
Mnemonic: My Blood Group Is Rh Positive

My

Myasthenia Gravis

Blood

Blood transfusion reaction

Group

Good pasture syndrome,

Graves disease

Is

Immune hemolytic anaemia,

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

R

Rh incompatibility,

Rheumatic fever

H

Hyperacute transplant rejection

Positive

Pemphigus (Bullous),

Pernicious Anemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pernicious anaemia is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Natural Killer (NK) cells participate in Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity.

options.label: B
options.text: Opsonisation involves IgG antibodies coating cells, enhancing phagocytosis via Fc receptors.

options.label: C
options.text: When antibodies deposit in intracellular tissues, the injury is due to inflammation and not phagocytosis or cell lysis.

options.label: D
options.text: Myasthenia gravis is an example of antibody-mediated cell surface receptor dysfunction.

questions.correct_answer: C. When antibodies deposit in intracellular tissues, the injury is due to inflammation and not phagocytosis or cell lysis.
questions.explanation:
Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Opsonisation and Phagocytosis
(Option B)

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia

  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

Complement activation

and inflammation
(Option C)

Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation, not phagocytosis or cell lysis. The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, leading to the attraction of neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors. Activated leukocytes release enzymes, resulting in tissue damage.

  • Goodpasture syndrome

  • Acute rheumatic fever

Antibody-dependent

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
(Option A)

Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death.

  • Pernicious anemia

  • Insulin resistant diabetes

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic)
(Option D)

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).

  • Graves disease

  • Myasthenia gravis

Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Opsonisation and Phagocytosis
(Option B)

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia

  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

Complement activation

and inflammation
(Option C)

Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation, not phagocytosis or cell lysis. The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, leading to the attraction of neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors. Activated leukocytes release enzymes, resulting in tissue damage.

  • Goodpasture syndrome

  • Acute rheumatic fever

Antibody-dependent

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
(Option A)

Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death.

  • Pernicious anemia

  • Insulin resistant diabetes

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic)
(Option D)

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).

  • Graves disease

  • Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with swelling in his face and legs, decreased urine output, and dark-colored urine. His parents reported that he had a sore throat about three weeks ago, which resolved without treatment. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I hypersensitivity

options.label: B
options.text: Type II hypersensitivity

options.label: C
options.text: Type III hypersensitivity

options.label: D
options.text: Type IV hypersensitivity

questions.text: Which of the following is typically associated with localized immune-complex mediated hypersensitivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Serum sickness

options.label: B
options.text: Arthus reaction

options.label: C
options.text: Membranous glomerulonephritis

options.label: D
options.text: Reactive arthritis

questions.explanation:
Systemic type III hypersensitivity

Localised type III hypersensitivity

Involves the widespread formation of immune complexes in circulation and can deposit in various tissues and organs throughout the body, including the kidneys (leading to glomerulonephritis), joints, skin, blood vessels, and other sites. (e.g., in chronic infections or autoimmune diseases).

Immune complexes are deposited at specific sites of antigen exposure, such as the skin (as in the Arthus reaction) or joint spaces, leading to local inflammation (localized swelling, redness, pain) and tissue damage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with jaundice and fatigue, recently diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Further investigation reveals abnormal liver function tests, indicating hepatic injury. Which of the following statements regarding the mechanisms of hypersensitivity involved in this case is true?

options.label: A
options.text: CD8+ T cells differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells upon antigen exposure

options.label: B
options.text: CD4+ T cells differentiate into Th2 cells upon exposure to antigen

options.label: C
options.text: Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas-Fas ligand pathway

options.label: D
options.text: Perforin-granzyme-dependent killing is a mechanism employed by CD4+ T cells

questions.correct_answer: C. Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas-Fas ligand pathway
questions.explanation:
Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Cytokine-mediated inflammation
(mediated by CD4+ T cells)

CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells (Options A and B ruled out).

Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis. Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation.
  • Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity)
  • Granulomas
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • IBD
  • Psoriasis

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells)


 

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection. CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing (Option D ruled out) and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells. (Option C)
  • Type 1 DM
  • Hepatic injury in HBV infection
  • Graft vs host disease

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of persistent cough and unintentional weight loss. The physician suspects a TB infection and performs a tuberculin skin test. Which of the following is not an example of the type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with this test?

options.label: A
options.text: Contact dermatitis from poison ivy exposure.

options.label: B
options.text: Rheumatoid arthritis.

options.label: C
options.text: Crohn's disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Reactive arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Type V hypersensitivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibodies bind to cell surface receptors, leading to altered cellular function

options.label: B
options.text: Immune complexes form and deposit in tissues, triggering localized inflammation and damage.

options.label: C
options.text: Antibodies target cell surface antigens, resulting in complement activation and cell destruction.

options.label: D
options.text: IgE antibodies mediate the release of histamine from mast cells, causing immediate allergic reactions.

questions.correct_answer: A. Antibodies bind to cell surface receptors, leading to altered cellular function

questions.text: Which of the following sequences correctly describes the phases of pathogenesis in Type III hypersensitivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Formation of immune complexes → Inflammation and tissue injury → Deposition in blood vessels.

options.label: B
options.text: Deposition of immune complexes → Formation of antibodies → Tissue injury and inflammation.

options.label: C
options.text: Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury.

options.label: D
options.text: Antibody production → Immune complex formation → Activation of cytotoxic T cells.

questions.correct_answer: C. Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury.
